poem:
**Morning at the Lake in Carinthia**

The larch trees double themselves
in the lake—a glass, a mirror.  
I thought of swimming, 
cutting the surface into ripples,  
but chose instead to float,  
head tipped back in reverence,  
letting the cool embrace  
hold me in this chapel of water.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Swanning around the Austrian lakes: a trip to Carinthia The lake was perfectly still, larch trees reflected in its glassy surface, hills folding into each other in the distance. I thought about swimming across it – a distance of about 1km – but once I was immersed in the cool, tranquil water, front-crawling through it with my head down lost its appeal. This was a moment to stop and take in the beauty of my surroundings.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
